alert.note: Alert for Mora; San Miguel; Taos (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 30 at 10:41PM MDT until July 01 at 12:15AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has extended the * Flash Flood Warning for... The Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar in... Southeastern Taos County in north central New Mexico... Western Mora County in northeastern New Mexico... Northwestern San Miguel County in northeastern New Mexico... * Until 1215 AM MDT. * At 1041 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms were starting to redevelop on the east side of the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar with the potential for additional development more centrally over the burn scar. Excessive runoff and flash flooding will remain possible. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will immediately impact Guadalupita to Mora to Sapello and San Ignacio. Any resulting debris flows may consist of ash, soot, rock, mud, vegetation, burned timber and other loose materials. HAZARD...Heavy rainfall from thunderstorms in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening runoff and flash flooding of areas in and around the Hermits Peak and Calf Canyon Burn Scar. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Mora, Ledoux, Morphy Lake State Park, Tierra Monte, Cleveland, La Cueva, Gascon, Holman, Sapello, Chacon, South Carmen, Monte Aplanado, Rociada, Manuelitas, Rainsville, Luceros, San Ignacio in Guadalupe County, Golondrinas, El Turquillo and Guadalupita. This includes the following recreation areas... El Porvenir Campground and Morphy Lake State Park. This includes the following highways... State Road 94 between Mile Markers 1 and 18. State Road 518 between Mile Markers 9 and 45. State Road 434 between Mile Markers 0 and 15. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Runoff from rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon wildfire burn area. Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages.
